summary: The document outlines the case of Yurily Ivanovich NOSENKO, a Soviet KGB officer who defected to the U.S. in 1964. It details his involuntary confinement by the Agency for approximately three years, his eventual freedom, and his subsequent employment as a consultant. The document also explores the legal basis for his confinement, the involvement of various U.S. agencies, the conditions of his confinement, and the results of investigations into his authenticity as a defector. Controversial aspects of his treatment during confinement are also mentioned.
key_findings: NOSENKO defected to the U.S. in 1964 and was involuntarily confined for about three years before gaining freedom and becoming a U.S. citizen in 1974.
The legal basis for his confinement was discussed with high-level officials, with conditions established by the Office of Security.
Investigations by the Office of Security and the FBI concluded NOSENKO was a bona fide defector, despite some skepticism within the Agency.
NOSENKO was employed by the Agency as a consultant, leveraging his background and experience.
Controversial treatment during confinement included the use of prostitutes during a trip to Florida.
